prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 279GHz continuum and N2H+ observations
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To obtain high resolution N2H+, H2CO and continuum emission map. N2H+ measurements will be combined with the N2D+ measurements to study the deuterium chemistry along the evolutionary stages of high-mass dense cores. H2CO line ratios will be used to derive the temperature distribution of dense cores, and will be compared with the temperature derived from CH3CN lines. Combine the temperature distribution results and the continuum emission, we will study the density structure of all our targets and the evolution of density profiles.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The spectral resolution for N2H+ of 0.13km/s will help us to resolve hyperfine structure of the proposed lines. The resolution of 0.29km/s for H2CO is to garantee an proper fitting to the line profile to get good temperature estimation, considering in some cold region, the line width is only about ~1.5km/s. Other lines are selected for detection. We set the spectra average number to reduce the data rate, H(30)alpha line is usually several km/s wide, so a spectral resolution of ~1km/s is OK.

The resolution of ~0.5"is needed to resolve dense cores (0.01pc) and the Jeans-fragmentation length in these regions. Previous interferometer observations show that the largest scale in our sources are all <~8" (G034-G2(MM2): Tan et al. 2013; 18089-1732:Beuther et al. 2004; G5.890.39:Hernandez-Hernandez, et al 2014).

We propose to perform a small pilot study towards 3 targets at 1.3 mm and 1.1 mm. The narrow band correlator will be used to cover the lines we propose to observe and provide a spectral resolution of 0.13~km/s at 1.1~mm. Single dish studies show the N2H+(3-2) emission towards our sample have the intensity of >0.7K (Fontani et al. 2011), which converts to 3.6Jy per single dish beam. Previous interferometer observations show that the source has a size ~5" (Tan et al. 2013), so the N2H+(3-2) intensity would be 36mJy/beam for our proposed observation. Tan et al. (2013) also shows that the 1.3mm continuum of G034-G2(MM2) is about > 1mJy. We propose to reach a line sensitivity of 9mJy to ensure >~4 sigma detection of the line, and will also ensure >~10 sigma for the continuum for all sources. (G034-G2(MM2): Tan et al. 2013; 18089-1732:Beuther et al. 2004; G5.890.39:Hernandez-Hernandez, et al 2014).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 230GHz continuum and N2D+ observations
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To obtain high resolution N2D+,CH3CN, H2CO and continuum emission map. N2D+ measurements will be combined with the N2H+ measurements to study the deuterium chemistry along the evolutionary stages of high-mass dense cores. H2CO and CH3CN lines will be used to derive the temperature distribution of dense cores. Combine the temperature distribution results and the continuum emission, we will study the density structure of all our targets and the evolution of density profiles.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The spectral resolution for N2D+ of 0.15km/s will help us to resolve hyperfine structure of the proposed lines. The resolution of 0.38km/s for CH3CN and 0.19km/s for H2CO is to avoid line confusion and garantee an proper fitting to the line profile to get good temperature estimation. Other lines are selected for detection. We set the spectra average number to reduce the data rate, H(46) line is usually several km/s wide, so a spectral resolution of ~1km/s is OK.

The resolution of ~0.5"is needed to resolve dense cores (0.01pc) and the Jeans-fragmentation length in these regions. Previous interferometer observations show that the largest scale in our sources are all <~10" (G034-G2(MM2): Tan et al. 2013; 18089-1732:Beuther et al. 2004; G5.890.39:Hernandez-Hernandez, et al 2014).

We propose to perform a small pilot study towards 3 targets at 1.3 mm and 1.1 mm. The narrow band correlator will be used to cover the lines we propose to observe and provide a spectral resolution of 0.15~km/s at 1.3~mm. Single dish studies show the N2D+(2-1) emission towards our sample have the intensity of >0.08K (18089-1732, Fontani et al. 2011), assuming the same exitation condition, N2D+(3-2) would be ~3.3 times of the one for N2D+(2-1) (according to CDMS), which converts to 2.9Jy per single dish beam. Previous interferometer obseravtions show that the source has a size ~5" (Beuther et al. 2004), so the N2D+(3-2) intensity would be 29mJy/beam for our proposed observation. We propose to reach a line sensitivity of 7mJy to ensure >~4 sigma detection of the line, and will also ensure >~10 sigma for the weakest continuum source for the eakest continuum source, G034-G2(M2)(1mJy, Tan et al. 2013).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 279GHz continuum and N2H+ observations for G034-G2(MM2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To obtain high resolution N2H+, H2CO and continuum emission map for G034-G2(MM2). N2H+ measurements will be combined with the N2D+ measurements to study the deuterium chemistry along the evolutionary stages of high-mass dense cores. H2CO line ratios will be used to derive the temperature distribution of dense cores, and will be compared with the temperature derived from CH3CN lines. Combine the temperature distribution results and the continuum emission, we will study the density structure of all our targets and the evolution of density profiles.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The spectral resolution for N2H+ of 0.13km/s will help us to resolve hyperfine structure of the proposed lines. The resolution of 0.29km/s for H2CO is to garantee an proper fitting to the line profile to get good temperature estimation, considering in some cold region, the line width is only about ~1.5km/s. Other lines are selected for detection. We set the spectra average number to reduce the data rate, H(30)alpha line is usually several km/s wide, so a spectral resolution of ~1km/s is OK.

The resolution of ~0.5"is needed to resolve dense cores (0.01pc) and the Jeans-fragmentation length in these regions. Previous interferometer observations show that the largest scale in our sources are all <~10" (G034-G2(MM2): Tan et al. 2013; 18089-1732:Beuther et al. 2004; G5.890.39:Hernandez-Hernandez, et al 2014).

We propose to perform a small pilot study towards 3 targets at 1.3 mm and 1.1 mm. The narrow band correlator will be used to cover the lines we propose to observe and provide a spectral resolution of 0.13~km/s at 1.1~mm. Single dish studies show the N2H+(3-2) emission towards our sample have the intensity of >0.7K (Fontani et al. 2011), which converts to 3.6Jy per single dish beam. Previous interferometer observations show that the source has a size ~5" (Tan et al. 2013), so the N2H+(3-2) intensity would be 36mJy/beam for our proposed observation. Tan et al. (2013) also shows that the 1.3mm continuum of G034-G2(MM2) is about > 1mJy. We propose to reach a line sensitivity of 9mJy to ensure >~4 sigma detection of the line, and will also ensure >~10 sigma for the continuum for all sources. (G034-G2(MM2): Tan et al. 2013; 18089-1732:Beuther et al. 2004; G5.890.39:Hernandez-Hernandez, et al 2014).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 230GHz continuum and N2D+ observations for G034-G2(MM2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To obtain high resolution N2D+,CH3CN, H2CO and continuum emission map for G034-G2(MM2). N2D+ measurements will be combined with the N2H+ measurements to study the deuterium chemistry along the evolutionary stages of high-mass dense cores. H2CO and CH3CN lines will be used to derive the temperature distribution of dense cores. Combine the temperature distribution results and the continuum emission, we will study the density structure of all our targets and the evolution of density profiles.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The spectral resolution for N2D+ of 0.15km/s will help us to resolve hyperfine structure of the proposed lines. The resolution of 0.38km/s for CH3CN and 0.19km/s for H2CO is to avoid line confusion and garantee an proper fitting to the line profile to get good temperature estimation. Other lines are selected for detection. We set the spectra average number to reduce the data rate, H(46) line is usually several km/s wide, so a spectral resolution of ~1km/s is OK.

The resolution of ~0.5"is needed to resolve dense cores (0.01pc) and the Jeans-fragmentation length in these regions. Previous interferometer observations show that the largest scale in our sources are all <~10" (G034-G2(MM2): Tan et al. 2013; 18089-1732:Beuther et al. 2004; G5.890.39:Hernandez-Hernandez, et al 2014).

We propose to perform a small pilot study towards 3 targets at 1.3 mm and 1.1 mm. The narrow band correlator will be used to cover the lines we propose to observe and provide a spectral resolution of 0.15~km/s at 1.3~mm. Single dish studies show the N2D+(2-1) emission towards our sample have the intensity of >0.08K (18089-1732, Fontani et al. 2011), assuming the same exitation condition, N2D+(3-2) would be ~3.3 times of the one for N2D+(2-1) (according to CDMS), which converts to 2.9Jy per single dish beam. Previous interferometer obseravtions show that the source has a size ~5" (Beuther et al. 2004), so the N2D+(3-2) intensity would be 29mJy/beam for our proposed observation. We propose to reach a line sensitivity of 7mJy to ensure >~4 sigma detection of the line, and will also ensure >~10 sigma for the weakest continuum source for the eakest continuum source, G034-G2(M2)(1mJy, Tan et al. 2013).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to perform a pilot study to investigate the evolution of high-mass dense cores. We will focus on density structure and deuterium chemistry. Our sources are selected from a previous single-dish observational N2H+/N2D+ survey, spanning a range of evolutionary stages, from high-mass starless core (HMSC) to high-mass protostellar object (HMPO) and ultra-compact HII (UCHII) region. The core density profile is commonly used as an important input initial condition parameter for high-mass star formation modelling, but it is still not well understood. With the proposed high sensitivity and angular resolution observations, we can measure the temperature and density profile of the high-mass cores and further investigate the relation between the density profiles and the evolutionary stages; we can study the N2D+/N2H+ emission structure towards high-mass objects, and if this is an evolutionary tracer at high-mass core scale (~0.01pc), and the deuterium chemistry around/in UCHII regions. Our ALMA proposal will provide unprecedented high-resolution details of the structure and chemistry of high-mass cores, helping us understand the early stages of high-mass star formation.
